column4: are you using generic kernel?  if so, try with "sudo apt-get install linux-backports-modules-wireless-karmic-generic"
That module contains all the cutting edge wireless drivers for Ubuntu Karmic from the testing repositories which haven’t yet been officially released, hope it could help
ok i will install that is there something i must do after i install that?
not really, just Open up “Software Sources” and browse to the “Updates” tab, make sure the karmic-backports option is ticked
i have only ssh :( just apt-get update and upgrade?
:( you'll have to enable that locally(I mean you'll need to do that on the computer that is having that wireless problem)
well its the same on the computer i only have a login terminal
well its the same on the computer i only have a login terminal im using the computer as HTPC wich only runs xbmc
it has to look this way, check the backports section: http://www.flickr.com/photos/jonolumb/4112112734/
i dont have a graphic interface i just have a terminal  i will try reboot to see if its working now
once i run sudo apt-get install linux-backports-modules-wireless-karmic-generic  does that install the latest wireless drivers?
once i run sudo apt-get install linux-backports-modules-wireless-karmic-generic does that automaticly install the latest wireless drivers?
it will install wireless drivers for Ubuntu Karmic which haven’t yet been officially released

i know but what i dont understand is once i run the apt-get install does that install the drivers and i have nothing els to do? because u showed me something wich i cant do i have only a terminal to type commands
is there a way to check what my wifi is using for the driver version?
version information for each MadWifi module is sent to the system log when  the modules are loaded. You can check that log with "dmesg" and "lsmod", for example.
im using ath5k not madwifi since madwifi is not used anymore
ath5k well is was formerly known as madwifi, sorry if I sounded "old"
